title: Modeling a Periodic Context-Jump Rope, Part C

content.description:
The figure shows two people turning a jump rope at a constant rate as a third person attempts to jump over the rope as it passes below their feet. Point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> is located in the middle of the jump rope and is touching the ground at time <math alttext="t equals 0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"> <mi>t</mi> <mo>=</mo> <mn>0</mn> </math> seconds. The next time that point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> touches the ground is at time <math alttext="t equals 1" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>1</mn></math> second. The maximum height of <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground is <math alttext="78" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mn>78</mn></math> inches. As the rope turns, the height of <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground periodically increases and decreases.

The sinusoidal function <math alttext="h" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>h</mi></math> models the height of point <math alttext="X" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>X</mi></math> above the ground, in inches, as a function of time <math alttext="t" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><mi>t</mi></math>, in seconds.
content.question:
Part C

Refer to the graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> in part (A). The <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 1"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and the <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 2"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(i) On the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"> <mfenced> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </mfenced> </math>, which of the following is true about <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math>?

<math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> is positive and increasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is positive and decreasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and increasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and decreasing.

(ii) Describe how the rate of change of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is changing on the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>.

frqParts.text:
Part C

Refer to the graph of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> in part (A). The <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="G"><mi>G</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 1"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub></math>, and the <math alttext="t"><mi>t</mi></math>-coordinate of <math alttext="J"><mi>J</mi></math> is <math alttext="t subscript 2"><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></math>.

(i) On the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"> <mfenced> <mrow> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>1</mn> </msub> <mo>,</mo> <msub> <mi>t</mi> <mn>2</mn> </msub> </mrow> </mfenced> </math>, which of the following is true about <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math>?

<math alttext="h"> <mi>h</mi> </math> is positive and increasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is positive and decreasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and increasing.

<math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is negative and decreasing.

(ii) Describe how the rate of change of <math alttext="h"><mi>h</mi></math> is changing on the interval <math alttext="open parentheses t subscript 1 comma t subscript 2 close parentheses"><mfenced><mrow><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>1</mn></msub><mo>,</mo><msub><mi>t</mi><mn>2</mn></msub></mrow></mfenced></math>.

skill.text: Skill 2.A: Identify information from graphical, numerical, analytical, and verbal representations to answer a question or construct a model, with and without technology.
